org.mu.util

Class Maybe<T,E extends Throwable>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.mu.util.Maybe<T,E>

  • public abstract class Maybe<T,E extends Throwable>
extends Object
    Class that wraps checked exceptions and tunnel them through stream operations.

    The idea is to wrap checked exceptions inside Stream>, then map(), flatMap(), filter() away through normal stream operations, and only unwrap/collect at the end. Exception is only thrown at the "collecting" step. For example: 

    
   static List<byte[]> readFiles(Collection<File> files) throws IOException {
     Stream<Maybe<byte[], IOException>> stream = files.stream()
         .map(Maybe.wrap(Files::toByteArray));
     return Maybe.collect(stream);  // IOException throws here.
   }
    A longer stream chain example: 
    
   private Job fetchJob(long jobId) throws IOException;
   
   List<Job> getPendingJobs() throws IOException {
     Stream<Maybe<Job, IOException>> stream = pendingJobIds.stream()
         .map(Maybe.wrap(this::fetchJob))
         .filter(Maybe.byValue(Job::isPending));
     return Maybe.collect(stream);
   }
    To log and swallow exceptions: 
    
   private <T> Stream<T> logAndSwallow(Maybe<T> maybe) {
     return maybe.catching(logger::warn);
   }

   List<String> getPendingJobNames() {
     return pendingJobIds.stream()
         .map(Maybe.wrap(this::fetchJob))
         .flatMap(this::logAndSwallow)
         .filter(Job::isPending)
         .map(Job::getName)
         .collect(Collectors.toList());
   }

      • orElseThrow

        public final <X extends Throwable> T orElseThrow(java.util.function.Supplier<X> exceptionSupplier)
                                          throws X extends Throwable
        Either returns success value, or throw exception created by exceptionSupplier. The original causal exception of type E is set as cause of the thrown exception of type X.

        This is useful when the encapsulated exception may be from a different thread (like the case of catchException(java.lang.Class<E>, java.util.concurrent.CompletionStage<T>). Directly propagating exception from a different thread can result in confusing stack trace.

        Throws:
        X extends Throwable

      • catching

        public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> catching(java.util.function.Consumer<? super E> handler)
        Catches and handles exception with handler, and then skips it in the returned Stream. This is specially useful in a Stream chain to handle and then ignore exceptional results.

      • byValue

        public static <T,E extends Throwable> java.util.function.Predicate<Maybe<T,E>> byValue(java.util.function.Predicate<T> condition)
        Turns condition to a Predicate over Maybe. The returned predicate matches any Maybe with a matching value, as well as any exceptional Maybe so as not to accidentally swallow exceptions.

      • wrap

        public static <T,E extends Throwable> java.util.function.Supplier<Maybe<T,E>> wrap(CheckedSupplier<T,E> supplier)
        Wraps supplier to be used for a stream of Maybe.

        Unchecked exceptions will be immediately propagated without being wrapped.

      • wrap

        public static <F,T,E extends Throwable> java.util.function.Function<F,Maybe<T,E>> wrap(CheckedFunction<F,T,E> function)
        Wraps function to be used for a stream of Maybe.

        Unchecked exceptions will be immediately propagated without being wrapped.

      • wrap

        public static <A,B,T,E extends Throwable> java.util.function.BiFunction<A,B,Maybe<T,E>> wrap(CheckedBiFunction<A,B,T,E> function)
        Wraps function to be used for a stream of Maybe.

        Unchecked exceptions will be immediately propagated without being wrapped.

      • wrap

        public static <T,E extends Throwable> java.util.function.Supplier<Maybe<T,E>> wrap(CheckedSupplier<T,E> supplier,
                                                                                   Class<E> exceptionType)
        Wraps supplier to be used for a stream of Maybe.

        Normally one should use wrap(CheckedSupplier) unless E is an unchecked exception type.

        For GWT code, wrap the supplier manually, as in: 

        
   private static <T> Supplier<Maybe<T, FooException>> foo(
       CheckedSupplier<T, FooException> supplier) {
     return () -> {
       try {
         return Maybe.of(supplier.get());
       } catch (FooException e) {
         return Maybe.except(e);
       }
     };
   }

      • wrap

        public static <F,T,E extends Throwable> java.util.function.Function<F,Maybe<T,E>> wrap(CheckedFunction<F,T,E> function,
                                                                                       Class<E> exceptionType)
        Wraps function to be used for a stream of Maybe.

        Normally one should use wrap(CheckedFunction) unless E is an unchecked exception type.

        For GWT code, wrap the function manually, as in: 

        
   private static <F, T> Function<F, Maybe<T, FooException>> foo(
       CheckedFunction<F, T, FooException> function) {
     return from -> {
       try {
         return Maybe.of(function.apply(from));
       } catch (FooException e) {
         return Maybe.except(e);
       }
     };
   }

      • wrap

        public static <A,B,T,E extends Throwable> java.util.function.BiFunction<A,B,Maybe<T,E>> wrap(CheckedBiFunction<A,B,T,E> function,
                                                                                             Class<E> exceptionType)
        Wraps function to be used for a stream of Maybe.

        Normally one should use wrap(CheckedBiFunction) unless E is an unchecked exception type.

        For GWT code, wrap the function manually, as in: 

        
   private static <A, B, T> BiFunction<A, B, Maybe<T, FooException>> foo(
       CheckedBiFunction<A, B, T, FooException> function) {
     return (a, b) -> {
       try {
         return Maybe.of(function.apply(a, b));
       } catch (FooException e) {
         return Maybe.except(e);
       }
     };
   }

      • catchException

        public static <T,E extends Throwable> CompletionStage<Maybe<T,E>> catchException(Class<E> exceptionType,
                                                                                 CompletionStage<T> stage)
        Returns a wrapper of stage that if stage failed with exception of exceptionType, that exception is caught and wrapped inside a Maybe to complete the wrapper stage normally.

        This is useful if the code is interested in recovering from its own exception while not wanting to mess with other types. Neither of CompletionStage.exceptionally(java.util.function.Function<java.lang.Throwable, ? extends T>) and CompletionStage.handle(java.util.function.BiFunction<? super T, java.lang.Throwable, ? extends U>) methods allow selective exception recovery because you can't re-throw the Throwable unless it's unchecked.
